Covers the major events, philosophical and religious traditions of pre-modern China, including Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: History of China to 1644

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of Chinese culture, society, government and diplomacy between1644 and the present. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Modern China

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Study of the causes, conduct and consequences of the Second World War. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: World War II

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Study of the political, social and cultural development of Russia from the Kievan era through the Napoleonic invasion. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: Russia to 1861

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of political, cultural and intellectual trends in modern Russia with emphasis upon the Revolutions of 1917, the Soviet Union, and its successor states. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Russia Since 1861

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the Great War's origins, major and minor battles, the role of technology, and the experience of soldiers. Examines the internal conflicts the war created, the ideologies it spawned, and the social relationships it permanently altered. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: World War I

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey and analysis of the Vietnam War with special emphasis on its impact on American and Indochinese society. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: The United States and Vietnam, 1945-1975

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: The tumultuous decade of the 1960s witnessed global political, social and cultural upheavals. We will study movements for change in the United States, as well as in Europe, China, Vietnam, and Latin American. Topics will include the New Left, the counterculture, and the student, civil rights, antiwar and women's movements. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: The 1960s: A World Transformed

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of colonial and revolutionary American history, emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include historical interpretations of Native American, French, Spanish, English, Dutch, and Russian interactions in North America as well as the causes of the American Revolution and formation of the new national government. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Colonial and Revolutionary America, 1600-1789

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of early national and antebellum America emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include the impact of westward expansion, slavery, religion, gender, the market economy, and political developments on the new nation. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Early National and Antebellum America, 1789-1850

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course will focus on global African history since the Age of Revolutions to the present with special attention to the movements and leaders in various fields who proposed strategies and led movements to advance Africa, Africans and the diaspora. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Black Movements and Messiahs

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the dramatic changes in Japan from the nineteenth century to the twenty-first century in a global, historical perspective. Through the lenses of imperialism and war, society and gender, and technology and environment, students will develop an understanding of Japan's place in our modern world. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: Modern Japan

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the political, social, and cultural history of Europe during the
long
nineteenth century from the French Revolution of 1789 to the outbreak of the First World War in 1914. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Europe in the 19th Century

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the political, social, and cultural history of Europe during the twentieth century from the outbreak of the First World War to the collapse of Communist states in Eastern Europe in 1989. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Europe in the 20th Century

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course explores transformations to major cities from the late-eighteenth century to the present day. Course themes include: industrialization, urban expansion, metropolitan regulation, imperial influence, identity formation, and the city as laboratory for monarchy/democracy/communism/fascism. We consider primary sources, secondary historical scholarship, and the writing of key figures in urban theory. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Urban History: The Modern Metropolis

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This survey course provides students with an overview of the development of civilization in South Asia (a region encompassing the countries of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal and Sri Lanka) from its earliest human occupants through the end of the heyday of the Mughal empire in the early 18th century CE. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Introduction to Early South Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Although Islam originated in Arabia, South Asian countries such as Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh today host among the largest populations of Muslims in the world. This survey course examines the introduction of Islam to South Asia in the 7th century CE and its subsequent development there through the mid-18th century. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Islam and Early South Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Special topics in ancient history that are not presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in Ancient History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Special topics related to African history which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in African History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics in Asian history, including the eastern Pacific region, which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in Asian History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics in European history which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in European History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics in Latin American and Caribbean history which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in Latin American and Caribbean History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics in the history of the Middle East which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in Middle East History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics in the history of the United States which are usually not covered in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics in U.S

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey analyzing Italy from unification (Risorgimento of the 1800s) to the present. While focusing on the history of the country in its multifaceted aspects, the course also offers a comparative approach, helping students analyze Italy in the context of European integration and major international developments. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Modern Italy and the World, 1861-Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of Brazil from pre-Columbian roots to present political controversies. Approaches environmental and cultural histories, including indigenous and Afro-Brazilian voices. Students will include primary sources and cultural artifacts, such as music, art, and poetry in their research. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: History of Brazil

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Treats a special topic or issue, offered as part of the honors program. Prerequisite: Honors candidacy (not restricted to candidacy in history). (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for degree credit.
Courses.name: Honors Colloquium

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores how historians can use art as historical source and how people have historically interpreted and analyzed art. Focus on art production/interpretation in Early Modern Europe (14th to 18th century), contemporary tastes, and cultural practices informing art production. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Art as History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A practical introduction to historical research and writing. Examines research methods and current theories of interpreting and evaluating the past. Prepares students for honors thesis development and writing. Required for and restricted to history honors students. Prerequisite: Junior standing as honors history major. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: Honors Methods

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Historical topics which are not usually presented in depth in regular courses. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Honors history thesis. Prerequisite: Junior standing. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer) May be repeated for up to 12 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Honors History Thesis

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of the Athens from the sixth century BCE to the end of the fourth. Topics include origins and evolution of democracy, the Persian wars, the rise and fall of the Athenian Empire, and the development of historiography, literature, art, and philosophy during the period. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Democratic Athens

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey of the achievements of Alexander and the culture of the new world he created. The personality and career of Alexander are examined as well as the rich diversity of the Hellenistic world: trade with India, religious syncretism, and the development of Hellenistic science and philosophy. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of Rome from its origins in the eighth century BCE to the fall of the Republic in the first century BCE. Topics include the sources for Roman history, the development, functioning, and ultimate failure of republican government, the Roman army, and Roman imperialism in Italy and the Mediterranean. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Roman Republic

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of Rome from the Emperor Augustus to Constantine, ca. 30 BCE - 337 CE. Topics include the sources for imperial Rome, the organization of imperial government, the provinces of Rome and provincial government, art and literature under the empire, the rise of Christianity, and the conversion of the Empire. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Roman Empire

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course examines the political, spiritual, intellectual, and social-economic developments of European history, c. 300-1000 CE. Special topics include the Christianization of the late Roman Empire and Byzantium, as well as the formation of Celtic and Germanic Kingdoms in the West. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Late Antiquity and the Early Middle Ages

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course examines the political, social-economic, intellectual, and spiritual developments of European history, c. 1000-1400 CE. Special topics include monasticism, sacral kingship, the crusades, and the medieval university. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Late Middle Ages

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Study Abroad project. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Independent Study

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of Europe from the end of the Middle Ages through the Renaissance to the Reformation and Counter-Reformation. Special attention is paid to changes in popular piety, political thought, religious representation, and the discovery of the New World. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: Renaissance and Reformation, 1300-1600

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Begins with the upheaval of the reformation, moves through the crisis of the 17th century and culminates with the democratic revolution of the 18th century. Examines the consolidation of the European state system, the propagation of modern science, discovery of overseas worlds, and the advent of the Industrial Revolution. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: Early Modern Europe, 1600-1800

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores how the United States has extended social justice to African Americans during the nation's history. Examines social justice for blacks and the impact of historic policies and practices on black life today. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4093.
Courses.name: The History of African Americans and Social Justice

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history and culture of the Byzantine Empire from the reign of Constantine I to the fall of Constantinople in 1453. Topics include the development of Christianity and the schism with the western church, the crusades, and Byzantine influence on Islam, Russia, the Ottomans, and the Renaissance. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Byzantine Empire

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of Greece from the late Bronze Age to the end of the Persian Wars. This class will focus particularly on the sources involved with reconstructing early Greek history, especially Herodotus and Homer, on the development of the Greek city-state or polis, and on the interaction between the Greeks and Near-eastern civilizations during this period, culminating in the wars between the Greeks and the Persian Empire. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Archaic Greece

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the trans-Atlantic slave trade with a primary focus on the role of Africa and Africans in creating the unique economy and culture of the trans-Atlantic world. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4123.
Courses.name: Africa and the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Changing values and attitudes toward childhood, family life, sexuality, and gender roles in Europe from the Renaissance to the present. The social impact of the Industrial Revolution, urbanization, demographic change, and the two world wars. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Society and Gender in Modern Europe

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey of the major developments in European thought and culture since the emergence of Romanticism. Topics include Romanticism, Darwinism, Marxism, and Modernism. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Intellectual History of Europe Since the Enlightenment

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of the British Isles from the ascension of Henry VII and the Tudor dynasty until the close of the Stuart Era in 1714. Special attention is given to the English Reformation, the Elizabethan years, the 17th Century Revolutions, and the birth of an overseas Empire. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: Tudor-Stuart England, 1485-1714

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course examines the social, political, and cultural aspects of the modern Latin American city from an interdisciplinary perspective. The course includes an introduction to urban studies concepts, and each semester is organized around a specific set of case studies. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Latin American City

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of the British Isles from the 1707 Act of Union between Scotland and England until the death of Queen Victoria in 1901. Special attention is given to the spread of Empire, industrialization, and the political, social, and cultural aspects of the Georgian and Victorian Eras. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Great Britain, 1707-1901

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of the British Isles from the death of Queen Victoria in 1901 to the reelection of Prime Minister Tony Blair in 2001. Special attention is given to the collapse of the British Empire, the birth of the welfare state, and the challenges inherent in the decline of British world power. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Great Britain,1901-2001

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the origins, history, and legacies of the European Holocaust. Traces the origins of anti-Semitism in Europe, the rise of Nazism in Germany, the path to genocide during World War II, and the role of victims, perpetrators, rescuers, and bystanders. Considers issues of memory and justice in the postwar era. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: History of the Holocaust

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: France from the salons of the Enlightenment to the Napoleonic Wars. The French Revolution will be explored in terms of politics and personalities, ideas and symbols, class and gender relations, and violence and terror. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: The Era of the French Revolution

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of French history from the overthrow of Napoleon to the 5th Republic, with emphasis on French politics, society, and culture. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: France Since 1815

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the political, economic, cultural, and social engagement of Africans, Europeans, and Native Americans across the Atlantic from 1400 to 1850. It uses a comparative lens to understand how interactions between Europe, Africa, and the Americas created enduring ties throughout the Atlantic Basin. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Atlantic World, 1400-1850

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Study of German history from the Age of Absolutism to the collapse of the German Empire at the end of the First World War. Special attention is paid to the Enlightenment and Romantic movements; nationalism and the unification of Germany; and evolving conflicts over the political and social order. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Germany, 1789-1918

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Study of German history from advent of the Weimar Republic to the end of the Third Reich with emphasis upon the failure of democratic government in the 1920s and the rise and fall of the National Socialist dictatorship. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Germany, 1918-1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the last half-century of Africa's history, focusing on the last few decades. Introduction of Africa's colonial past, revolutions and struggles for independence. Review of African development in the post-colonial and contemporary era, successes and failures of independent Africa, and the challenges the continent faces today. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4263.
Courses.name: Modern Africa

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the meaning of slavery around the world, both in ancient and modern times. This examination of how slavery differed in various cultures over time will allow students to explore the complexity of this labor relationship and gain a better understanding of how slavery was an integral part of world history. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4273.
Courses.name: Comparative Slavery

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the meaning of slavery around the world, both in ancient and modern times. This examination of how slavery differed in various cultures over time will allow students to explore the complexity of this labor relationship and gain a better understanding of how slavery was an integral part of world history. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with HIST 4273, AAST 4273.
Courses.name: Honors Comparative Slavery

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the challenges, debates, and ecologies of Latin America in order to understand the historical roots of current environmental crises. It engages a historiography on ecosystems found in the region. Uses environmental history texts and scholarly articles to build a layered and transnational approach. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Latin American Environmental History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: US-Western European Relations, from the Wilsonian era to the present, covering strategic, economic, and cultural aspects. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Transatlantic Relations, 1919-Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the place of religion in combat across the centuries. A case study approach is used to explore different conflicts from the twelfth century crusades against Muslim forces to 9/11. Investigates how religious motivations may or may not be related to other political, social, cultural, economic concerns. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Wars of Religion: From the Crusades to 9/11

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Main currents in Islamic theology and political philosophy from the Ottoman Empire to the end of the twentieth century. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Modern Islamic Thought

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course will examine the diverging and converging paths of Portugal and Spain during the early modern period (15th-17th centuries). We will chart their rise as global imperial powers and their initial declines. We'll explore the political, social, and religious contexts in which Golden Age Iberia flourished. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: Golden Age Portugal and Spain

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Middle East since 1914 addresses European colonialism, the rise of new social elites, independence, revolution, globalization, economic self-determination, persistent regional conflicts and ongoing battles over
cultural authenticity
. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Middle East since 1914

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduction to the history and development of the civil rights movement in the United States. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4383.
Courses.name: The American Civil Rights Movement

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: An examination of the historical development of the three great Islamic empires in the early modern period- the Ottomans, the Safavids of Iran, and the Mughals of India. Special attention given to imperial expansion, administrative structures, religious-legal establishment, and the formation of distinct traditions in political ideology, historiography, and the arts and sciences. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: Early Modern Islamic Empires, 1300-1750

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduces students to the history of Islam in East and Southeast Asia over the past 1,200 years. It focuses on the 18th-21st centuries when Muslims were part of everyday life in Asia and participated in the formation of majority and minority identities in the region. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Islam in Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course covers the transformation of social and cultural roles of women in the Middle East since the 19th Century. Emphases include political emancipation, religious reformation, artistic representation, and gendered re-definition. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: New Women in the Middle East

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: An analysis of Middle East history in the 17th-20th centuries which focuses on the social transformation of urban and rural life. Particular emphasis is given to the roles of economics, genealogy, art, and popular culture. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Social and Cultural History of the Modern Middle East

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course examines frontiers and borderlands in colonial Latin America and focuses on the regions of California, New Mexico, Texas, Brazil, and the Ro de la Plata. It demonstrates that frontiers and borderlands are defined by the absence of a hegemonic European power and associated with the prevalence of Indigenous norms. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Frontiers and Borderlands in Colonial Latin America

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: American westward expansion and its influence on national institutions and character. Emphasis on the pioneer family and the frontier's role in shaping American society, culture, economy, and politics. Topics include exploration, the fur trade, the cattle kingdom and the mining, farming, and military frontiers. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: The American Frontier

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the interactions between human culture and the natural environments: Concepts of nature in the West and elsewhere, dynamics of the Physical Environment, case studies in Regional Environmental History and the Politics of Environmental movements. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Environmental History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduction to the history and intellectual development of famous and not-so-famous African Americans. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4483.
Courses.name: African American Biographies

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of religion in early America, primarily from a social and cultural perspective. Topics will include region, social class, growth of institutions, slavery, print culture, and social reform in traditions including Protestantism, West African religion, Catholicism, Native American religion, and Judaism. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Religion in America to 1860

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Origin and development of the American party system from the implementation of the constitution to the election of McKinley. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years) This course is cross-listed with PLSC 4303.
Courses.name: History of Political Parties in the United States, 1789-1896

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Response of the party system to America's emergence as an industrial nation and world power from the election of 1896 to present. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years) This course is cross-listed with PLSC 4313.
Courses.name: History of Political Parties in the United States Since 1896

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of thought and society since the Civil War. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: American Social and Intellectual History Since 1865

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A cross-cultural study of those who chose or needed to leave the world of officialdom for the world of nature in early East Asia. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: The Recluse in Early East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of the political, social, and economic development of the antebellum South. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4563.
Courses.name: The Old South, 1607-1865

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of the development of the Civil War and postwar South to the present. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4573.
Courses.name: The New South, 1860 to the Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Designed to provide advanced undergraduate and graduate students with a comprehensive understanding of the full sweep of Arkansas history. The focus will be on social, economic and political history, and historiography. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Arkansas in the Nation

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course focuses on the French Colonial Mississippi Valley from 1698 until 1763. Activities for both French and non-French speaking students provide a rich environment to discuss encounters, subsistence strategies, and warfare faced by native peoples, missionaries, explorers, and colonists alike. Students will examine primary handwritten, transcribed, or translated sources. (Typically offered: Spring) This course is cross-listed with WLLC 4053, WLLC 4053H.
Courses.name: The Colonial French in the Mississippi Valley

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the changing nature of work in U.S. history from 1607 until 1877 including the ways that workers--individually and collectively-- understand the meanings of their labor and to the ways that notions of class, gender, ethnicity, and race inform these understandings. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: U.S

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of colonial America from 1600 to the end of the Seven Years War emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include Native American, French, Spanish, English, Dutch, and Russian interactions in North America and the larger Atlantic World. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Colonial America 1600-1763

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of revolutionary America emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include historical interpretations of the causes of the war, the impact of war on African Americans, women, loyalists, elite, and poor Americans. The course also examines the formation of the new national government. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Revolutionary America, 1763 to 1789

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A study of courtly culture and the religious world of Heian Japan. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Heian Japan (794-1192)

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A study of courtly culture and the religious world of Heian Japan. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is equivalent to HIST 4633.
Courses.name: Honors Heian Japan (794-1192)

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of the early United States emphasizing social and cultural perspectives. Topics addressed will include westward expansion, slavery, religion, and economic change. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Early American Republic, 1789-1828

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of antebellum U.S. emphasizing social and cultural perspectives. Topics addressed will include slavery, religion, gender, the market economy, regionalism, and political developments. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Antebellum America, 1828-1850

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey of political, social, and economic issues from the late antebellum period through Reconstruction. Emphasis is placed on the causes of the Civil War and the problems of postwar America. A brief examination of the Civil War is included. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Rebellion to Reconstruction, 1850-1877

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: An intensive study of the political, social, military, and economic aspects of the American Civil War period. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: The American Civil War

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores theoretical perspectives on global history through a treatment of the historiographical development of the field, readings of landmark texts, and selected case studies of global themes. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with INST 4693.
Courses.name: Approaching Global History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A survey of the impact of the Industrial Revolution, Imperialism, and progressivism upon American life and institutions. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: Emergence of Modern America, 1876-1917

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: The impact of World War I, the 1920s, and the Great Depression upon American society and culture. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: America Between the Wars, 1917-1941

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A general survey of American history since World War II with emphasis upon the presidency, reform movements, the Cold War, and cultural developments. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Recent America, 1941 to the Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course will trace the rise of the ideological and political struggles over social and economic development and the security regimes designed to thwart socialist revolution and political mobilization. The influence of the United States in Latin American security regimes and
containment
activities will receive special attention. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Cold War in Latin America: Revolutions, Violence, and Politics

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Survey of American foreign relations from the American Revolution through the Spanish-American War. Principal topics include isolationism, freedom of the seas, manifest destiny and continental expansion, overseas expansion, and the diplomacy of war and peace. Emphasis on the relationship between domestic politics and foreign affairs. Prerequisite: HIST 2003. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the United States, 1776-1900

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: America's development as a world power. The course examines U.S. relations with Europe, Latin America, and East Asia, plus America's first approach to the Middle East. Particular emphasis is placed on America's involvement in World War I and World War II. Prerequisite: HIST 2013. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the United States, 1900-1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: U.S. involvement in world affairs since WWII. The Cold War from an international perspective, including strategies, nuclear deterrence, conflicts, economic developments, cultural relations among allies and adversaries. Post-Cold War scenarios, including war on terrorism. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the US, 1945 to Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course examines the history of Mexico from the wars of independence to the present. Emphasis will be placed on the turbulent nineteenth century and the Mexican Revolution. Themes covered include colonial legacies, national identities, popular culture, emigration, and relations with the United States. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: History of Modern Mexico

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the course of Indian history from the 1758 Battle of Plassey to eventual independence from Great Britain in 1948. Special attention is given to India's place within the British Empire, particularly the East Indian Company, the Indian Mutiny, the Raj, the rise of Gandhi, and India's independence movement. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Colonial India, 1758-1948

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of the Nordic lands, including Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, from 1500 to the present. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Modern Scandinavia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the diverse experiences of slaves and free Blacks in colonial Spanish and Portuguese America from 1500 to around 1888, demonstrating that bondage and the practice of African slavery was a pillar of political authority in colonial Latin America. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4813.
Courses.name: Africans and Slavery in Colonial Latin America

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course centers on the comparative study of Atlantic World freedom movements from the perspective of the African Diaspora. It focuses on the histories, meanings, legacies of the various types of black emancipation in the Atlantic World and the cultural technologies that enabled them. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Black Freedom in the Age of Emancipation

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Prompts students to explore the various historical processes related to the global diffusion of and engagement with soccer. Examines the ways soccer has reflected the broader, ongoing process of globalization, with players, ideas, tactics, and wealth circulating throughout the globe. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Global History of Soccer

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A critical introduction to the most important sources and major themes, both textual and archeological, for the study of early China. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Early Chinese Empires: Mythology, Archeology, and Historiography

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A critical introduction to the most important sources and major themes, both textual and archeological, for the study of early China. (Typically offered: Spring) This course is equivalent to HIST 4853.
Courses.name: Honors Early Chinese Empires: Mythology, Archeology, and Historiography

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduces the major East Asian philosophical and religious traditions including Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism, and Shintoism. Read original sources in translation, such as Analects, and explore perspectives that stem from the traditions as they bear on contemporary global issues. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: Classical Thought in East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduces the major East Asian philosophical and religious traditions including Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism, and Shintoism. Read original sources in translation, such as Analects, and explore perspectives that stem from the traditions as they bear on contemporary global issues. (Typically offered: Fall) This course is equivalent to HIST 4863.
Courses.name: Honors Classical Thought in East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines the history of Germany since the end of the Second World War including political division and economic recovery, dissident movements in East Germany and alternative cultures in West Germany, reunification in 1990, and the legacy of Nazism and the Holocaust. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Germany since 1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Explores the emergence of epidemics against the backdrop of the nation state and anxieties over women, the lower classes, and other marginalized groups. The rise of modern health programs illuminates the cultural construction of medicine, the biases of scientific inquiry, and the tensions among paternalism, liberty, and prejudice. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Health and Disease: 1500 to the Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Required for all history majors. Examines research methods and current theories of interpreting and evaluating the past. Emphasizes skills of analysis, synthesis, and integration. Students produce a primary source-based research paper. A grade of a B or better will satisfy the Fulbright senior writing requirement. Prerequisite: History major; senior standing. (Typically offered: Fall and Spring)
Courses.name: Senior Capstone Seminar

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A music and arts view of urban and popular culture of the Edo period of Japan (1600-1868). Readings drawn from history, literature, aesthetics, religion and science. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Music and the Arts of Edo Japan 1600-1868

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A historical, sociocultural, and inter-arts approach to the medieval lyric-drama Japanese Noh, a form of masked theater with roots reaching beyond the 14th century. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Reading Japanese Noh as Cultural History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: A historical, sociocultural, and inter-arts approach to the medieval lyric-drama Japanese Noh, a form of masked theater with roots reaching beyond the 14th century. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is equivalent to HIST 4913.
Courses.name: Honors Reading Japanese Noh as Cultural History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examination of the Song dynasty (960-1279) concentrating on the education and role of the scholar-official and the literatus. Readings drawn from history, literature, personal diaries, travel accounts, political memoranda, and scientific writings. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Song China 960-1279

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examination of the Song dynasty (960-1279) concentrating on the education and role of the scholar-official and the literatus. Readings drawn from history, literature, personal diaries, travel accounts, political memoranda, and scientific writings. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is equivalent to HIST 4923.
Courses.name: Honors Song China (960-1279)

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Confucian, Daoist, and Buddhist ideas of ideal communities ('utopias'), of imaginary places ('paradise islands'), and of the afterlife ('heaven and hell') in East Asia will be traced in a broad sweep across literature, painting, and the performing arts. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Ad Paradisum: Utopias, imaginary places, and the afterlife in East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: This course will examine the changing nature of work in U.S. history from 1877 until the present. It will pay particular attention to the ways that workers--individually and collectively--understand the meanings of their labor and to the ways that notions of class, gender, ethnicity, and race inform these understandings. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: U.S

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduction to the history of women in Sub-Saharan Africa, starting in the early 18th century through the 20th century. Focus on women and the transatlantic slave trade, women's influence in pre-colonial religious, political, and cultural institutions, and women's experiences under colonial rule and in post-colonial Africa. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit. This course is cross-listed with AAST 4953.
Courses.name: The History of Sub-Saharan African Women

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Introduction to the history of women in Sub-Saharan Africa, starting in the early 18th century through the 20th century. Focus on women and the transatlantic slave trade, women's influence in pre-colonial religious, political, and cultural institutions, and women's experiences under colonial rule and in post-colonial Africa. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit. This course is cross-listed with HIST 4953, AAST 4953.
Courses.name: Honors The History of Sub-Saharan African Women

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Examines key issues related to societal change in the Third World, including various views and theories of international development and modernization. Other major issues explored include social inequalities, food and hunger, population, environment, trade and globalization, international aid, and the roles of state, market, and civil society. (Typically offered: Irregular) This course is cross-listed with AAST 4963.
Courses.name: Third World Underdevelopment and Modernization

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Important trends in Italian culture between the 14th and 16th centuries, including the birth of humanism, new understandings of the past,
new
political ideologies, scientific innovation, and famous art produced in the Western tradition. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Senior thesis. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Senior Thesis

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: History of the Ottoman Empire from its emergence as frontier principality in Anatolia ca. 1300, through its heyday as a major imperial power on three continents in the fifteenth through the eighteenth centuries, ending with its encounter with western imperialism and nationalism in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: History of the Ottoman Empire, 1300-1923

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4003.) History of the Athens from the sixth century BCE to the end of the fourth. Topics include origins and evolution of democracy, the Persian wars, the rise and fall of the Athenian Empire, and the development of historiography, literature, art, and philosophy during the period. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4003 and HIST 5003. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Democratic Athens

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4013.) A survey of the achievements of Alexander and the culture of the new world he created. The personality and career of Alexander are examined as well as the rich diversity of the Hellenistic world: trade with India, religious syncretism, and the development of Hellenistic science and philosophy. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4013 and HIST 5013. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4033.) History of Rome from the Emperor Augustus to Constantine, ca. 30 BCE - 337 CE. Topics include the sources for imperial Rome, the organization of imperial government, the provinces of Rome and provincial government, art and literature under the empire, the rise of Christianity, and the conversion of the Empire. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4033 and HIST 5033. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Roman Empire

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Directed readings in the field of European history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 12 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in European History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in American History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer)
Courses.name: Research Problems in European History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer)
Courses.name: Research Problems in American History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in Latin American history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Research Problems in Latin American History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Readings in Asian History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in Asian history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Research Problems in Asian History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4193.) Examines the history of the British Isles from the death of Queen Victoria in 1901 to the reelection of Prime Minister Tony Blair in 2001. Special attention is given to the collapse of the British Empire, the birth of the welfare state, and the challenges inherent in the decline of British world power. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4193 and HIST 5193. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Great Britain,1901-2001

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4203.) Examines the origins, history, and legacies of the European Holocaust. Traces the origins of anti-Semitism in Europe, the rise of Nazism in Germany, the path to genocide during World War II, and the role of victims, perpetrators, rescuers, and bystanders. Considers issues of memory and justice in the postwar era. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4203 and HIST 5203. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: History of the Holocaust

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings in Latin American history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Readings in Latin America History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings in African history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Readings in African History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in African history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Research Problems in African History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings in Middle Eastern history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Readings in Middle Eastern History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings in Medieval history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in Medieval History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in Middle Eastern history. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Research Problems in Middle Eastern History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in Medieval history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Research Problems in Medieval History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Directed readings in the field of British history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 12 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in British History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Readings in Ancient history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in Ancient History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Research problems in Ancient history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Research Problems in Ancient History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4393.) An examination of the historical development of the three great Islamic empires in the early modern period- the Ottomans, the Safavids of Iran, and the Mughals of India. Special attention given to imperial expansion, administrative structures, religious-legal establishment, and the formation of distinct traditions in political ideology, historiography, and the arts and sciences. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4393 and HIST 5393. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Early Modern Islamic Empires, 1300-1750

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4403.) Introduces students to the history of Islam in East and Southeast Asia over the past 1,200 years. It focuses on the 18th-21st centuries when Muslims were part of everyday life in Asia and participated in the formation of majority and minority identities in the region. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4403 and HIST 5403. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Islam in Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Graduate readings in Caribbean history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in Caribbean History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Independent research in Caribbean history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Research Problems in Caribbean History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Graduate readings in Atlantic world history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 6 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in Atlantic History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4483.) Introduction to the history and intellectual development of famous and not-so-famous African Americans. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4483 and HIST 5483. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: African American Biographies

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4493.) History of religion in early America, primarily from a social and cultural perspective. Topics will include region, social class, growth of institutions, slavery, print culture, and social reform in traditions including Protestantism, West African religion, Catholicism, Native American religion, and Judaism. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4493 and HIST 5493. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Religion in America to 1860

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4503.) Origin and development of the American party system from the implementation of the constitution to the election of McKinley. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4503 and HIST 5503. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: History of Political Parties in the United States, 1789-1896

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4513.) Response of the party system to America's emergence as an industrial nation and world power from the election of 1896 to present. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4513 and HIST 5513. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: History of Political Parties in the United States Since 1896

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4023.) History of Rome from its origins in the eighth century BCE to the fall of the Republic in the first century BCE. Topics include the sources for Roman history, the development, functioning, and ultimate failure of republican government, the Roman army, and Roman imperialism in Italy and the Mediterranean. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4023 and HIST 5523. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Roman Republic

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4543.) Survey of thought and society since the Civil War. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4543 and HIST 5543. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: American Social and Intellectual History Since 1865

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4553.) A cross-cultural study of those who chose or needed to leave the world of officialdom for the world of nature in early East Asia. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4553 and HIST 5553. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: The Recluse in Early East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4563.) Survey of the political, social, and economic development of the antebellum South. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4563 and HIST 5563. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: The Old South, 1607-1865

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4573.) Survey of the development of the Civil War and postwar South to the present. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4573 and HIST 5573. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: The New South, 1860 to the Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4583.) Designed to provide advanced undergraduate and graduate students with a comprehensive understanding of the full sweep of Arkansas history. The focus will be on social, economic and political history, and historiography. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4583 and HIST 5583. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Arkansas in the Nation

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4593.) This course focuses on the French Colonial Mississippi Valley from 1698 until 1763. Activities for both French and non-French speaking students provide a rich environment to discuss encounters, subsistence strategies, and warfare faced by native peoples, missionaries, explorers, and colonists alike. Students will examine primary handwritten, transcribed, or translated sources. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4593 and HIST 5593. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: The Colonial French in the Mississippi Valley

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4603.) Examines the changing nature of work in U.S. history from 1607 until 1877 including the ways that workers--individually and collectively-- understand the meanings of their labor and to the ways that notions of class, gender, ethnicity, and race inform these understandings. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4603 and HIST 5603. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: U.S

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4613.) History of colonial America from 1600 to the end of the Seven Years War emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include Native American, French, Spanish, English, Dutch, and Russian interactions in North America and the larger Atlantic World. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4613 and HIST 5613. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Colonial America 1600-1763

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4623.) History of revolutionary America emphasizing economic, social, and cultural perspectives. Topics include historical interpretations of the causes of the war, the impact of war on African Americans, women, loyalists, elite, and poor Americans. The course also examines the formation of the new national government. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4623 and HIST 5623. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Revolutionary America, 1763 to 1789

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4633.) A study of courtly culture and the religious world of Heian Japan. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4633 and HIST 5633. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Heian Japan 794-1192

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4643.) History of the early United States emphasizing social and cultural perspectives. Topics addressed will include westward expansion, slavery, religion, and economic change. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4643 and HIST 5643. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Early American Republic, 1789-1828

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4653.) History of antebellum U.S. emphasizing social and cultural perspectives. Topics addressed will include slavery, religion, gender, the market economy, regionalism, and political developments. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4653 and HIST 5653. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Antebellum America, 1828-1850

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4663.) A survey of political, social, and economic issues from the late antebellum period through Reconstruction. Emphasis is placed on the causes of the Civil War and the problems of postwar America. A brief examination of the Civil War is included. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4663 and HIST 5663. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Rebellion to Reconstruction, 1850-1877

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4673.) An intensive study of the political, social, military, and economic aspects of the American Civil War period. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4673 and HIST 5673. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: The American Civil War

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4383.) Introduction to the history and development of the civil rights movement in the United States. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4383 and HIST 5683. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The American Civil Rights Movement

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4053.) This course examines the political, social-economic, intellectual, and spiritual developments of European history, c. 1000-1400 CE. Special topics include monasticism, sacral kingship, the crusades, and the medieval university. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4053 and HIST 5693. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Late Middle Ages

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Special topics. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 9 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Special Topics

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4723.) The impact of World War I, the 1920s, and the Great Depression upon American society and culture. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4723 and HIST 5723. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: America Between the Wars, 1917-1941

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Directed readings in the field of Global history. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Irregular) May be repeated for up to 12 hours of degree credit.
Courses.name: Readings in Global History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4753.) Survey of American foreign relations from the American Revolution through the Spanish-American War. Principal topics include isolationism, freedom of the seas, manifest destiny and continental expansion, overseas expansion, and the diplomacy of war and peace. Emphasis on the relationship between domestic politics and foreign affairs. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4753 and HIST 5753. Prerequisite: HIST 2003. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the United States, 1776-1900

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4763.) America's development as a world power. The course examines U.S. relations with Europe, Latin America, and East Asia, plus America's first approach to the Middle East. Particular emphasis is placed on America's involvement in World War I and World War II. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4763 and HIST 5763. Prerequisite: HIST 2013. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the United States, 1900-1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4773.) U.S. involvement in world affairs since WWII. The Cold War from an international perspective, including strategies, nuclear deterrence, conflicts, economic developments, cultural relations among allies and adversaries. Post-Cold War scenarios, including war on terrorism. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4773 and HIST 5773. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: Diplomatic History of the US, 1945 to Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4783.) This course examines the history of Mexico from the wars of independence to the present. Emphasis will be placed on the turbulent nineteenth century and the Mexican Revolution. Themes covered include colonial legacies, national identities, popular culture, emigration, and relations with the United States. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4783 and HIST 5783. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: History of Modern Mexico

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4793.) Examines the course of Indian history from the 1758 Battle of Plassey to eventual independence from Great Britain in 1948. Special attention is given to India's place within the British Empire, particularly the East Indian Company, the Indian Mutiny, the Raj, the rise of Gandhi, and India's independence movement. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4793 and HIST 5793. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Colonial India, 1758-1948

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4803.) Examines the history of the Nordic lands, including Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, from 1500 to the present. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4803 and HIST 5803. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Modern Scandinavia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4813.) Explores the diverse experiences of slaves and free Blacks in colonial Spanish and Portuguese America from 1500 to around 1888, demonstrating that bondage and the practice of African slavery was a pillar of political authority in colonial Latin America. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4813 and HIST 5813. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Africans and Slavery in Colonial Latin America

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4823.) This course centers on the comparative study of Atlantic World freedom movements from the perspective of the African Diaspora. It focuses on the histories, meanings, legacies of the various types of black emancipation in the Atlantic World and the cultural technologies that enabled them. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4823 and HIST 5823. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Black Freedom in the Age of Emancipation

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4433.) An analysis of Middle East history in the 17th-20th centuries which focuses on the social transformation of urban and rural life. Particular emphasis is given to the roles of economics, genealogy, art, and popular culture. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4433 and HIST 5833. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Social and Cultural History of the Modern Middle East

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4233.) Explores the political, economic, cultural, and social engagement of Africans, Europeans, and Native Americans across the Atlantic from 1400 to 1850. It uses a comparative lens to understand how interactions between Europe, Africa, and the Americas created enduring ties throughout the Atlantic Basin. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4233 and HIST 5843. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Atlantic World, 1400-1850

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4853.) A critical introduction to the most important sources and major themes, both textual and archeological, for the study of early China. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4853 and HIST 5853. (Typically offered: Spring)
Courses.name: Early Chinese Empires: Mythology, Archeology, and Historiography

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4863.) Introduces the major East Asian philosophical and religious traditions including Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism, and Shintoism. Read original sources in translation, such as Analects, and explore perspectives that stem from the traditions as they bear on contemporary global issues. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4863 and HIST 5863. (Typically offered: Fall)
Courses.name: Classical Thought in East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4873.) Examines the history of Germany since the end of the Second World War including political division and economic recovery, dissident movements in East Germany and alternative cultures in West Germany, reunification in 1990, and the legacy of Nazism and the Holocaust. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4873 and HIST 5873. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Germany since 1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4883.) Explores the emergence of epidemics against the backdrop of the nation state and anxieties over women, the lower classes, and other marginalized groups. The rise of modern health programs illuminates the cultural construction of medicine, the biases of scientific inquiry, and the tensions among paternalism, liberty, and prejudice. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4883 and HIST 5883. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Health and Disease: 1500 to the Present

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4253.) Study of German history from advent of the Weimar Republic to the end of the Third Reich with emphasis upon the failure of democratic government in the 1920s and the rise and fall of the National Socialist dictatorship. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4253 and HIST 5893. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Germany, 1918-1945

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4903.) A music and arts view of urban and popular culture of the Edo period of Japan (1600-1868). Readings drawn from history, literature, aesthetics, religion and science. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4903 and HIST 5903. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Music and the Arts of Edo Japan 1600-1868

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4913.) A historical, sociocultural, and inter-arts approach to the medieval lyric-drama Japanese Noh, a form of masked theater with roots reaching beyond the 14th century. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4913 and HIST 5913. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Reading Japanese Noh as Cultural History

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4923.) Examination of the Song dynasty (960-1279) concentrating on the education and role of the scholar-official and the literatus. Readings drawn from history, literature, personal diaries, travel accounts, political memoranda, and scientific writings. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4923 and HIST 5923. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Song China 960-1279

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4933.) Confucian, Daoist, and Buddhist ideas of ideal communities ('utopias'), of imaginary places ('paradise islands'), and of the afterlife ('heaven and hell') in East Asia will be traced in a broad sweep across literature, painting, and the performing arts. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4933 and HIST 5933. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Ad Paradisum: Utopias, imaginary places, and the afterlife in East Asia

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4943.) This course will examine the changing nature of work in U.S. history from 1877 until the present. It will pay particular attention to the ways that workers--individually and collectively--understand the meanings of their labor and to the ways that notions of class, gender, ethnicity, and race inform these understandings. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4943 and HIST 5943. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: U.S

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4953.) Introduction to the history of women in Sub-Saharan Africa, starting in the early 18th century through the 20th century. Focus on women and the transatlantic slave trade, women's influence in pre-colonial religious, political, and cultural institutions, and women's experiences under colonial rule and in post-colonial Africa. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4953 and HIST 5953. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The History of Sub-Saharan African Women

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4963.) Examines key issues related to societal change in the Third World, including various views and theories of international development and modernization. Other major issues explored include social inequalities, food and hunger, population, environment, trade and globalization, international aid, and the roles of state, market, and civil society. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4963 and HIST 5963. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Third World Underdevelopment and Modernization

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Important trends in Italian culture between the 14th and 16th centuries, including the birth of humanism, new understandings of the past,
new
political ideologies, scientific innovation, and famous art produced in the Western tradition. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4143.) A survey of the major developments in European thought and culture since the emergence of Romanticism. Topics include Romanticism, Darwinism, Marxism, and Modernism. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4143 and HIST 5983. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Intellectual History of Europe Since the Enlightenment

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: Master's Thesis. Prerequisite: Graduate standing. (Typically offered: Fall, Spring and Summer) May be repeated for degree credit.
Courses.name: Master's Thesis

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4213.) France from the salons of the Enlightenment to the Napoleonic Wars. The French Revolution will be explored in terms of politics and personalities, ideas and symbols, class and gender relations, and violence and terror. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4213 and HIST 6013. (Typically offered: Fall Odd Years)
Courses.name: The Era of the French Revolution

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4133.) Changing values and attitudes toward childhood, family life, sexuality, and gender roles in Europe from the Renaissance to the present. The social impact of the Industrial Revolution, urbanization, demographic change, and the two world wars. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4133 and HIST 6033. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Society and Gender in Modern Europe

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4163.) Examines the history of the British Isles from the ascension of Henry VII and the Tudor dynasty until the close of the Stuart Era in 1714. Special attention is given to the English Reformation, the Elizabethan years, the 17th Century Revolutions, and the birth of an overseas Empire. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4163 and HIST 6063. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: Tudor-Stuart England, 1485-1714

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4073.) Examines the history of Europe from the end of the Middle Ages through the Renaissance to the Reformation and Counter-Reformation. Special attention is paid to changes in popular piety, political thought, religious representation, and the discovery of the New World. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4073 and HIST 6073. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Renaissance and Reformation, 1300-1600

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4083.) Begins with the upheaval of the reformation, moves through the crisis of the 17th century and culminates with the democratic revolution of the 18th century. Examines the consolidation of the European state system, the propagation of modern science, discovery of overseas worlds, and the advent of the Industrial Revolution. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4083 and HIST 6083. (Typically offered: Spring Odd Years)
Courses.name: Early Modern Europe, 1600-1800

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4093.) Explores how the United States has extended social justice to African Americans during the nation's history. Examines social justice for blacks and the impact of historic policies and practices on black life today. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4093 and HIST 6093. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The History of African Americans and Social Justice

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4113.) History of Greece from the late Bronze Age to the end of the Persian Wars. This class will focus particularly on the sources involved with reconstructing early Greek history, especially Herodotus and Homer, on the development of the Greek city-state or polis, and on the interaction between the Greeks and Near-eastern civilizations during this period, culminating in the wars between the Greeks and the Persian Empire. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4113 and HIST 6113. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Archaic Greece

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4173.) This course examines the social, political, and cultural aspects of the modern Latin American city from an interdisciplinary perspective. The course includes an introduction to urban studies concepts, and each semester is organized around a specific set of case studies. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4173 and HIST 6173. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: The Latin American City

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4183.) Examines the history of the British Isles from the 1707 Act of Union between Scotland and England until the death of Queen Victoria in 1901. Special attention is given to the spread of Empire, industrialization, and the political, social, and cultural aspects of the Georgian and Victorian Eras. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4183 and HIST 6183. (Typically offered: Fall Even Years)
Courses.name: Great Britain 1707-1901

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4103.) Examines the history and culture of the Byzantine Empire from the reign of Constantine I to the fall of Constantinople in 1453. Topics include the development of Christianity and the schism with the western church, the crusades, and Byzantine influence on Islam, Russia, the Ottomans, and the Renaissance. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4103 and HIST 6203. (Typically offered: Irregular)
Courses.name: Byzantine Empire

Courses.subject: HIST
Courses.description: (Formerly HIST 4223.) Survey of French history from the overthrow of Napoleon to the 5th Republic, with emphasis on French politics, society, and culture. Graduate degree credit will not be given for both HIST 4223 and HIST 6223. (Typically offered: Spring Even Years)
Courses.name: France Since 1815

Courses.subject: HIST
